results.title: Darwin was right!
results.brief_description: Fun and games with the animals at the Goologul Gardens including seals, bears and monkeys. Focusses mainly on chimpanzees with footage of them at various “human” activities - playing drums, fiddling with a hand-cranked camera, bathing a baby etc.

results.title: Darwin and the theory of natural selection [b&w]
results.brief_description: Young Charles Darwin’s voyage on HMS Beagle resulted in discoveries that have had a profound effect on nearly every field of human knowledge. Through Darwin’s observations off the coasts and islands of South America and experiments made in England, we see how this scientist developed his Theory of Natural Selection. Many rare views of animal and plant life were photographed on the Galapagos Islands.

results.title: Darwin's finches: clues to the origin of species
results.creator_credit: Herbert Schick and Film Associates of California
results.brief_description: A simple introduction to the evidence in the Galapagos Islands fauna which Darwin first interpreted as due to natural selection of variants, particularly the adaptive radiation of the finches and iguanas into different ecological roles. Suitable for upper primary and secondary levels.

results.title: Darwin's evolutionary stakes
results.creator_credit: Deborah Szapiro, Freerange Animation, New South Wales Film and Television Office, SBS Independent, Australian Film Commission and Andrew Horne
results.brief_description: A delightful and pertinent animation about Darwin’s evolutionary theory. Nicely punned, the human race has now been called. From the dinosaurs to present we get a graphic but comic explanation as to how we have arrived to today. As the race is battled out many species die along the way in the advent of disease and things such as technology, but If Darwin’s Evolutionary Stakes’ is right, it is only with “a short hair and half a brain” that we ‘humans’ make the photo finish. Written and performed by Patrick Burns.

results.title: Darwin's body snatchers (A)
results.creator_credit: Laurel Productions, Channel 4, U K and Chris Oxley
results.brief_description: This program looks at the export trade in Aboriginal skeletons, skulls and body parts rife during the nineteenth century and which continued up until 1940. Anthropologists and museums influenced by the work of Charles Darwin sought these remains for scientific study and museum exhibition. Australian doctors, scientists and supposedly respectable citizens may have colluded in both grave robbing and “killing to order”, to fulfil the European demand for the supply of Aboriginal bodies, which were treated as commodities. The program looks at shifts in museum policy and the efforts by groups such as the Tasmanian Aboriginal Centre to have these remains repatriated from overseas institutions back to Australia for proper burial by their descendants.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Laurel Productions, Channel 4, U K and Chris Oxley

results.title: Dartmouth: the Royal Navy College
results.creator_credit: Ivan Scott, Spectator Productions and Michael Hankinson
results.brief_description: The training of the navy cadets in the English Navy - these young boys join the navy cadets at the age of 13.1/2 years. Each cadet gets a shilling a week pocket money.

results.title: Dartmouth
results.creator_credit: John Richardson, Kestrel Film Productions and David Morgan
results.brief_description: Dartmouth Dam, on the Mitta Mitta River in Victoria, has been designed to manage the waters of the River Murray for irrigation and urban needs. This film tells the story of the making of Dartmouth Dam including the study of plant and animal life. Reminiscences about the old Dartmouth township, and plans for the new town of Dartmouth. Narrated by Simon Chilvers.

results.title: Darrow = Clarence Darrow: attorney for the damned
results.creator_credit: KCET (Television station : Los Angeles, Calif.), Heus-Stept Productions, Richard Heus, Stephen Stept and John David Coles
results.brief_description: Born in 1857 in Ohio, Clarence Darrow was to become one of the most famous and highly recognised lawyers in America, most notably through the defence of Eugene Debs during the Pullman railroad strike (1894), the Nathan Leopold and Richard Loeb murder trial (1924) and the John Scopes “Monkey trial” (1925). He was a defender and a champion of the poor, an intellect, and a paradox, leaving his successful country practice in Ohio to become a Chicago based lawyer where he entertained and became the darling of the young intellectuals, his Chicago apartment the site for frequent gatherings. In 1907 Darrow successfully defended Bill Haywood and other leaders of the Western Federation of Miners, accused in the bombing-assassination of the former governor of Idaho but in Los Angeles in 1912, it was Darrow himself who was on trial, charged with an attempted bribe of a juror. This made-for-television biographical dramatization of Darrow’s life provides an insight into this brilliant, somewhat unorthodox, lawyer who relied upon the power of the spoken word. Starring Kevin Spacey as Clarence Darrow, with Erin Cressida Wilson, Rebecca Jenkins, Chris Cooper, Paul Klementowicz, Calista Flockhart.
